summary: The Young Americans Financial Literacy Act establishes a competitive grant program within the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. It funds the creation of "centers of excellence" to support research, development, and implementation of financial literacy education for young people (ages 8-24) and their families. The bill authorizes between $27.5 million and $55 million annually until fiscal year 2029. These grants, awarded to partnerships of institutions like universities and nonprofits, will focus on core financial concepts, with priority given to programs serving at-risk populations and using evidence-based methods to improve financial stability and knowledge.
